Description: HO scale model train table representing Milwaukee. Contains a scavenger hunt with seasonal pieces switched out regularly.
Topics: trains, modeling, display, scavenger hunt, city, Milwaukee
Copy:
All Aboard!
Trains and railways have been a 'model' of innovation for hundreds of years, leading to advances in industry, agriculture, and transportation. Powered by steam, diesel fuel, or electricity, trains represent one of the most important ways that people and goods travel. Trains have also been a staple of pop culture and have been featured in some of our favorite movies. From Thomas the Tank Engine to The Hogwarts Express, these favorites take us on adventures and spark our imaginations. What is YOUR favorite? Today, trains and railways embody the technological advancements we've seen accelerate around the globe. From smart sensors and automated inspection equipment to computer programs that maximize fuel use, trains continue to carry us into the future.
Train Time
Before trains, every town across the country set their own clocks based on solar noon, the moment when the sun is at its highest point in the sky. In Milwaukee, solar noon happens about a minute before it happens in Waukesha and about 14 minutes before it happens in Eau Claire. Clocks were different everywhere you went, but no one could get anywhere fast enough for it to matter. Then trains happened. Trains need schedules, not just for passengers, but also for safety. If your local clock is 14 minutes faster or slower than someone else's local clock, how can you coordinate? Railway companies were the first to set standard times. Trains ran on standardized timetables set by the companies. To a railway company, it was the same time in Chicago and Eau Claire as it was in Milwaukee and Minneapolis. Eventually, the railroad companies convinced governments to divide North America into five time zones. Today, the United States has nine different time zones.
Staying on Track
How do trains stay on the tracks? Trains are massive and they have a lot of momentum. Newton's 1st Law of Motion says that objects that are moving want to keep moving in a straight line. But train routes aren't perfectly straight lines. When something with wheels goes around a curve, the outside wheels have farther to go and need to turn faster. The wheels on a car turn at different speeds thanks to something called a differential. Trains don't have a differential. Their wheels turn at the same speed. What's the solution? Train wheels aren't cylinders, they're cone-shaped and wider on the inside. If the track curves to the right, the train shifts to the left. Because the wheels have a slight cone shape, and are wider on the inside, the left wheels are now just a little bigger than the wheels on the right. This means that the left wheels travel a little bit farther than the ones on the right, all while turning at the same speed. Self-correcting wheels keep trains on the tracks.

Description: Flagship experience where guests can choose a foam sheet, feed it into a slot, and select a design to be laser cut into it. Guests are able to observe the laser cutting and take home their completed foam sheet.

Copy:
Sensor
1. 42KD Miniature Photoelectric Sensors
A very tiny version of the Rockwell Automation photoelectric sensor.
2. Rightsight™ Photoelectric Sensors
These sensors emit a beam of light. When an object like your foam sheet interrupts the beam, the sensor sends a signal to the Programmable Automation Controller or PAC. The PAC is the computer brain of the Dream Machine. It knows where each sensor is, so it knows where the object is.
3. 871P Versacube™ Inductive Proximity Sensors
Inductive Proximity Sensors work just like a metal detector. They generate an electromagnetic (EM) field to detect metal objects. The EM field induces a second EM field in a nearby metal object. The strength of the second EM field depends on the distance from the sensor to the object being sensed. Here,
Inductive Proximity Sensors indicate if the Infeed Gate is open or closed.
If the EM field is weak, that means the gate is open. If the EM field is strong, the gate is closed.
Inductive proximity sensors are used in food processing and manufacturing, robotic welding, and for packaging/ materials handling.
4. Visisight™ Sensors Photoelectric Sensors
How does the machine "know" where your order is? These sensors emit an eye-safe beam of red light. When something interrupts the beam, the sensor communicates that an object was detected. The ControlLogix® Programmable Automation Controller (PAC), the computer brain of the Dream Machine, knows where each sensor is, so it knows where the object is the instant it interrupts the beam. VisiSight™ Photoelectric Sensors are used in packaging, materials handling, and sortation.
Sensaguard™ RFID
You may have noticed that this exhibit is enclosed with acrylic panels. That's for your safety. These machines are smart, but they don't know you're here. They are programmed to do a specific thing and won't stop until they receive a signal to stop. Safety is incredibly important in factories and on assembly lines. Of course, people need to access these machines to perform troubleshooting and maintenance. That's why there are doors with SensaGuard™ sensors on them. SensaGuard™ sensors use a combination of RFID technology (radio signals that read a chip) and inductive proximity sensors (to detect metal) to let the machines know whether the panel doors are open or closed. If closed, everything runs just fine. If open, the machine stops.
More Copy:
Follow Your Order!
1. Infeed 
Place your foam sheet into the infeed slot.
2. Robotic Arm
A FANUC M420iA industrial robotic arm with a vacuum attachment is maneuvering your foam sheet. Gladys, the Tic-Tac-Toe-playing robot, is also an M420iA industrial robot.
3. Laser Cutter
Lasers are great for measuring, pointing, and fantastic for cutting stuff. Your foam sheet is being cut by a CO2 laser that emits a beam of coherent (focused), infrared light. Rather than moving on a gantry (an overhead framework), the laser beam is guided by moving lenses.
4. Conveyor
A conveyor is the perfect tool for moving products from one place to another. Each conveyor has two motors that are housed inside the shiny rollers. These motors are controlled by a PowerFlex® AC Drive, which in turn is controlled by the Programmable Automatic Controller.
5. Pick-Up

Control Cabinet
This cabinet houses the electronic brain of the Dream Machine. All the sensors, the AC motors, the laser cutters, and everything else are controlled by the ControlLogix® Programmable Automation Controller or PAC.
Kinetix® Servo Drives
Servos are a very precise and accurate electric motor. You can control their position, how fast they move, and how quickly they accelerate. Servo motors are controlled by servo drives. The Programmable Automation Controller or PAC (the computer brain of the Dream Machine) sends control signals to the Kinetix® Servo Drives. The drives amplify these signals and send them to the servos. Here in the Dream Machine, Kinetix® Servo Drives provide the motion control for the servo motors that move the laser cutters.
Armorblock® I/O
The Rockwell Automation ArmorBlock® I/O gathers information from the sensors and sends it to the Programmable Automation Controller (the computer brain), which determines what needs to be done.
Ethernet Control
One feature of Rockwell Automation systems is the Ethernet network, which allows all the systems to process information and communicate over a single network. Ethernet control gives operators a lot more control over the entire system. It also saves money on wiring and troubleshooting. And you can monitor and operate your factory from anywhere in the world.

Copy:
Build It!
Make the biggest machines.
Build It!
Build machines that move the Earth. It takes highly-skilled machinists, welders, and technicians to put it all together.
Casting
Metal is poured into giant molds to form the pieces of these massive earth movers. Casting allows Bucyrus to be innovative and save time and materials without sacrificing strength or quality.
Machining
The enormous pieces are then milled, ground, and cut with mind-boggling precision. Bucyrus Machining Equipment is some of the biggest and most precise in the world.
Welding
The process of fusing two or more pieces of metal together to form something new. It involves lots of current, high heat, and incredible amounts of precision and skill.
Big Machines Need Big Welds

Description: Tactile experience that allows users to feel a real fossil containing a fern encased in shale.
Copy:
Fern Fossils in Shale
Shale is a sedimentary rock that forms as silt and mud sink to the bottom of marshes, river deltas, and lakes. Time and pressure turn the mud into rock. Shale often forms the "cap" or roof of a coal seam. Black shale contains a lot of carbon, and forms when there is little or no oxygen in the mud. Organisms die and sink to the bottom. Layers of mud slowly settle on them. Time and pressure turn them fossils. These fern fossils are from the Pottsville Formation in the coal region of the Appalachian Mountains in Pennsylvania. They date back to the middle of the Pennsylvanian age (about 350-290 million years ago).

Description: Informational experience that shows how coal forms over time and explains energy transfer.
Copy:
‘Power Plants’
Coal Deposits - The Remains of Earth’s Ancient Fossils
Coal is… Carbon, Hydrogen, Oxygen, Sulfur
How Coal is Made
The Sun Lights and Heats the Earth. Plants Transform Solar Energy into Growth. When Plants Die, They Form Peat. Time, Pressure, and Heat Turn Plants into Coal. The Peat is Compressed in Sediment Layers to Form Lignite. Further Compression Forms Bituminous and Subbituminous Coal. The Older the Coal, the More Energy it Holds. Eventually, Anthracite Forms. We Turn Coal into Civilization. 
Stored Solar Energy
Each kilogram of coal contains 6.67 kW-h (kilowatt-hours) of energy. A kilogram of coal could power a 60-watt light bulb for 167 hours*.
*assuming a 100% efficiency rate; realistically a kilogram of coal would power a 60-watt lightbulb for about 50 hours.

Description: Informational experience that highlights different pieces of equipment required for welding and fun facts about welding.
Copy:
Welds
Big Welds Need Big Skill
Welding these big machines together is an art and a science. The welds must be straight, sound, and strong. Certified welders work with metal compositions (the filler material to fuse the thick, heavy pieces together. See the bevels, or angled grooves, on the joints? These allow welders to completely fill the joint area between the materials and to get a 100% sound weld. The welder makes the first pass, carefully guiding the molten metal into the joint. Plate thickness and the stress and strain to be put on the part determine if more welds are needed. The welds are actually stronger than the metal that the welder has fused together. After the welds cool, they are X-rayed for quality acceptance.
Tig Welding. Stick Welding. Mig Welding. Gas Welding. 
Did You Know?
The world's first industrial robot was made to spot weld. It was an industrial motorized arm weighing a staggering two tons.
Welding Helmet
The dark-tinted lens shade and helmet protect the welder from flash burns and “arc eye,” a painful eye _____ caused by the UV rays given off during welding.
Welding Gloves
Welders choose their gloves according to which technique they're using. Gloves are made from different kinds of animal hides and provide various levels of finger dexterity. They protect the welder from flames and electric shock.
Work Boots
Steel toe protects the welder from dropped equipment.
Welding Sleeves
Provides light protection against the flames and sparks while keeping the welder cool.
Welding Jacket
Protects the welder from heat, UV radiation, spatter, and sparks. 
Work Pants
Many welders prefer 100% cotton pants, like jeans, because they’re flame resistant and breathable. 
Welding Apron
Thick leather protects the welder from slag, flying sparks, and metal spatter.
More Copy:
Sparks Fly!
Welding produces very bright light, sparks, and extreme heat. Welders use several types of personal protective equipment (PPE) to stay safe. A welding helmet and safety glasses protect your eyes from sparks and UV radiation. Welding helmets have a dark lens to filter out bright light and to allow you to see the weld clearly. Welding gloves and a welding jacket protect your hands and body from heat, sparks, and slag. Slag is a by-product formed by the impurities in a metal that come out when heating metal to really high temperatures. The gloves are made of durable leather or Kevlar, and the jacket is made of a durable, flame-resistant material like cotton or wool.
Did You Know?
More than 50% of all human-made products require welding.

Description: Model of dampers, valves, and actuators on a small scale to show their practical purpose.
Copy:
Dampers, Valves, & Actuators
A damper is a plate that pivots open to allow warm or cool air into a room. It closes when the roam becomes too warm or too cool. Dampers are controlled by thermostats and moved by actuators. An actuator is a device that turns the energy of compressed air into a linear motion. They are connected to dampers by a series of linkages.
Johnson's Pneumatic System
When the thermostat reaches a set temperature, it sends a signal to an electropneumatic valve to turn the air pressure either on or off.
Air Pressure ON
A rubber diaphragm on the actuator inflates, which pushes on the linkages and opens the damper.
Air Pressure OFF
The rubber diaphragm deflates, the linkages relax, and the damper closes.

Description: Information about and demonstration of Johnson Controls' Metasys Home Automation systems.
Copy:
Metasys
One Brain to Rule them All
Human beings are pretty complicated. We have lots of systems. Circulatory, nervous, muscular, skeletal, digestive, respiratory, immune, and a few others. Each system depends on the others, and your body needs them all to work well in order for you to work well. Imagine if each of your systems had its own "brain" and those "brains" couldn't communicate with each other.
That would be a problem. Fortunately, all your systems are run by one complex, beautiful brain. Buildings are complicated, too, and they rely on many different systems. Heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems, lighting, security, fire protection. These systems have different controls and are made by different companies. Until recently, this meant lots of different "brains" that couldn't really interact. Metasys® is a complex, beautiful brain for buildings. Metasys® allows you to control all of a building's systems. It works with older systems and even systems from other manufacturers. It works online. It works on tablets and smartphones. Warren Johnson built a system that allowed you to control your environment. That was revolutionary back in the 19th Century. Today you trust Johnson Controls to deliver heating and cooling, giving you piece of mind. Today you rely on Johnson Controls to ensure your place of work or school is safe, secure, and comfortable environment.

Description: Mini version of the Wimshurst machine, an electrostatic generator.
Copy:
Wimshurst Static Machine
While Johnson was experimenting with compressed air, other innovators were exploring the possibilities of electricity.
A Shock, a Spark
The Wimshurst Machine consists of two insulated discs that rotate in opposite directions. The discs separate positive and negative charges, which are collected by metal combs and stored in Leyden Jars (capacitors). As the Wimshurst Machine rotates, the charges build and build until there is enough voltage for an electric spark to jump across the gap. Press the button. Wait 20 seconds to try again.

Pneumatic Dinosaur
Once upon a time, in a land before time, pneumatic dinosaurs roamed the land. As these giants strode upon the earth and swam in the primordial seas, levers forced compressed air into their mighty pistons transforming this force into movement. These gigantic creatures are gone (except for this one, the last of its kind), but their inspiration remains in pneumatic drills and bicycle pumps, HVAC control systems, giant pneumatic clocks, compressed air vehicles, pipe organs, exercise equipment, and anywhere else humans turn compressed air into work. 
Move the Levers. Control the Mighty Beast. Behold the Power of Compressed Air.

Description: Telegraph that highlights the spark gap, an invention that was instrumental to the development of the product.
Topics: telegraph, history, morse code, communication, engineering
Copy:
Wireless Telegraph
In the late 1800s, the telegraph was the only way to send an instant message to someone. The telegraph transformed the world and made communication much easier across distances. The problem was wires. You can't run wires from the shore to a ship, and ships were incredibly important to the global economy. People needed instant communication everywhere, and they needed to get rid of the wires. Warren Johnson's initial transmitter set-up consisted of a battery, a capacitor, an induction coil, and a spark gap. When you complete the circuit, the induction coil transforms low-voltage electricity from the battery into a high-voltage impulse, which jumps across the gap. This generates a pulse of radio waves that flies off in every direction. A coherer (radio-wave receiver) located somewhere else picks up this pulse of radio waves as a burst of static. A short burst of static became a Morse Code dot. A longer burst became a dash. Eventually, Johnson and his engineer Charles Fortier demonstrated their wireless telegraph system at the 1900 Paris Exposition with luminaries like Nikola Tesla, Guglielmo Marconi, and Thomas Edison.

Description: Telegraph with an accompanying morse code key where users are encouraged to spell out different words in morse code.
Topics: telegraph, history, morse code, communication, engineering
Copy:
Morse Code
It's 1836. Your name is Samuel Morse. You're a portrait painter and inventor originally from Charlestown, Massachusetts. Your job is to figure out a way to send instant messages across the country. You have a transmitter that allows you to send electrical impulses. You have a receiver that receives electrical impulses. You have electricity. You have wire. What do you do?
I Could Create a Code!
You could create a code. Each letter might be combination of short and long bursts of electricity. Dots and dashes (and empty space). Tiny bits of empty space between letters. Longer bits of empty space between words. You want your code to be as efficient as possible, so you assign the shortest series of dots and dashes to the letters we use most frequently. 'E' would be a single dot. 'T' would be a dash. ‘I' would be two dots. 'M' would be two dashes. And so on. Congratulations. You've invented Morse Code.

Description: Model thermostat that shows an early model of the invention.
Copy:
Origin of the Thermostat
Let's go back in time. 130 years should do it. Nice time machine, by the way. It's the late 1800s in Whitewater, Wisconsin. You're a professor. Your classroom is freezing. Your students are shivering in their coats and sweaters. Suddenly, a janitor opens the door and pops his head in, disrupting your class. He takes a look at the thermometer on the wall and pops out. The janitor runs down to the basement and turns on the boiler. Hot air starts surging through the vents. Your students start tearing off their coats and sweaters in an attempt to get comfortable. Now they're disrupting the class. Your classroom is never comfortable. Interruptions plague your lecture. How are you supposed to teach? How are your students supposed to learn? You get frustrated. If you're Warren Johnson, you turn that frustration into a brand new innovation called the thermostat.

Ding Dong
Nicknamed, "The Ding Dong", Les built it to test the magnetic quality of strings, which strings produced the most voltage, and what sound quality he could expect from plucking strings high versus low, etc. He quickly realized the benefit of this method. While other record producers and recording artists relied on electronic mixers to balance and engineer the sound, he was engaged in sound manipulation on the most basic levels. Les reveled in the subtleties.

Description: 500 vinyl records stacked on top one another to show a visual on how many discs Les Paul had to go through when recording his song "Lover."
Copy:
How Many Discs Does it Take to Create a New Sound?
Five hundred, give or take a tew. Computers have made it easy to record multiple tracks, overdub, and add effects. But the combination of these effects had never been done before Les Paul released "Lover" in 1948. He called his effects "The New Sound." It was a huge hit.
It was a complicated process. If he didn't like a particular take, he couldn't record over it. He had to start over with another disc.

Description: Visual experience that shows a 1951 Telecaster, the first solid-body electric guitar that Les Paul was heavily involved in the invention of. Guests can read about the friendly rivalry between Les Paul and Leo Fender.
Topics: Les Paul, Leo Fender, Gibson, Fender, guitar, electric-guitar, history, rivalry, invention, music
Copy:
Les & Leo
Gibson vs. Fender is one of music history's most iconic rivalries, yet Leo Fender and Les Paul shared a surprising friendship. Leo, a passionate electronics tinkerer who didn’t actually play guitar, started with a radio repair studio where he made his name selling musical equipment like public address systems, amplifiers, and Hawaiian guitars. He would often visit Les Paul's garage studio in L.A. where they discussed electronics and solid-body electric guitars. Leo created his first electric guitar prototype based off these visits and offered it to Les, inviting him to join Fender, but Les chose to stay with Gibson. The Telecaster, available in 1951, was the world’s first mass-produced and commercially successful solid-body electric guitar. Initially mocked for resembling a boat paddle, musicians soon discovered that Fender had provided them with a great-sounding, easily playable, and affordable instrument. It quickly became one of the most influential sounds of the 20th century, shaping the evolution of Rock 'n' Roll, R&B, and Country music. Seeing the success of Fender's Telecaster, Gibson got back in contact with Les Paul to create their own electric guitar. Les, who had figured out much of the invention in the decade earlier, said, “Fender was out first but I was way, way, way out front,” allowing for the quick release of the Gibson Les Paul in 1952. Les acknowledged Leo Fender's impact, stating, "Leo did me a favor. I couldn't move Gibson with an atomic bomb. It took Leo Fender to wake Gibson up." This rivalry spurred innovation, shaping their distinct guitar sounds.

Description: Users can view the first ever neck-mounted harmonica holder with a small blurb of accompanying text.
Topics: Les Paul, history, invention, harmonica, music
Copy:
Les' First Invention
Flip-able harmonica holder
Harmonica holders were available in the 1920s, but they held the harmonica in one position. When he was around 13 years old, Les was playing his guitar and harmonica in public. He wanted to be able to play both sides of his harmonica in order to change keys without putting his guitar down, so he invented a flip-able harmonica holder from metal coat hangers and a piece of wood. His design has evolved into a readily available product.

Description: Small copy-based experience that highlights the origins of Les Paul and Mary Ford's relationship.
Topics: Les Paul, Mary Ford, music, history
Copy:
Meeting Mary Ford
Iris Colleen Summers was Mary Ford's birth name. She was one of seven musical siblings whose father was a revival preacher. In 1944, Colleen was backing country singers as part of the Sunshine Girls trio. At the same time, Les Paul was living in Hollywood and looking for a female singer for his country music radio show. A friend suggested he listen to the Sunshine Girls. Les was impressed and called Colleen to audition. Colleen's friends knew she was a huge Les Paul fan. Surely one of her friends was pulling a prank. But she agreed to the audition. When the evening for the audition came, Les forgot about the meeting. He was mowing his lawn in a checkered shirt, baggy army pants and his old army boots. He hadn't even shaved. Colleen pulled up, "Can you tell me where the Les Paul studios are?" She followed Les' directions to the garage recording studio. The only way in was to climb through a window. Quite a bit later when Les crawled through the window, Colleen exclaimed, "That's not Les Paul! That's the gardener!" As she scrambled for the exit, Les picked up his guitar and let go with a fast run. Colleen stopped, "Oh my, you are Les Paul." For the radio show Colleen was "Mary Lou." Later, while the two were in Wisconsin, Les decided Colleen needed a new stage name. He picked up a Milwaukee phone book. They settled on "Mary Ford."

Description: Informational copy based experience where guests can learn about the times when Les was faced with hardship in his career, but still persisted through.
Topics: Les Paul, history, Gibson, reading-heavy, music
Copy:
Persistence
Focusing on the Future
When Les was 32, he and Mary Skidded off an icy bridge and down a ravine. Mary wasn’t badly hurt, but Les was a mess of broken bones. One doctor advised amputating Les’ shattered right arm, but Dr. Robert Knight - a fan - saved it. The best option was the fix the arm in place. Les had the surgeon set it so he’d still be able to play. During recovery, Les focused on his future. “The doctors said there was potential nerve damage, that I shouldn’t count on regaining full use of the hand, but I wasn’t buying it. I was determined it was going to come back and that I would play again.”
Meeting Bing
Bing Crosby’s weekly NBC radio show was the top show in America, and a 29-year-old Les Paul wanted to be on it. He didn’t know Bing, but left New York determined to meet him in Hollywood. After becoming a staff musician at NBC, Les noticed Bing’s habit of going into a tiny room for a few minutes of quiet before the show. One day, Les had his trio in that room rehearsing a hot number when Bing walked in. Bing hired all of them on the spot. “Being associated with Bing was a major step up.”
Persuading Gibson
As a young man of 26, Les went to Gibson with his solid body electric guitar, nicknamed "the Log." Despite its sweet tone and lack of feedback, Gibson turned it down, calling it a "broomstick with pickups on it." Les spent the next 10 years trying to convince Gibson to build a solid body electric guitar. Les' friend Leo Fender developed a solid body electric and gave Les a prototype. Les took the Fender Telecaster to Gibson, along with "the Log." "I believe the solid body guitar is going to be very important, and if you don't do something, Fender is going to rule the world." Les finally persuaded Gibson to design what became one of the most famous guitars in the world, the Les Paul Standard.

Description: One of the prototypes that would lead Les Paul to invent the solid-body electric guitar.
Copy:
Rail Guitar
"This was the direction I was craving to go. I didn't know it yet, but I was on my way to the solid body electric guitar." Les Paul began experimenting with electrifying his guitar when he was in his early teens. He connected a radio as an amplifier to his acoustic guitar, but he wanted to hear just the strings vibrate and he wanted the strings to vibrate longer. "Using a short length of steel railroad rail and two railroad spikes, I invented a device that could give me a consistent reference point for my experiments. I took a guitar string and fastened it at each end of the steel rail, using the spikes like a bridge and nut to raise the string so it could be plucked. Then I took a telephone microphone, wired it into Mom's radio for amplification, and placed it on the rail under the string. I soon figured out that the tremendous solidity of the rail allowed the string's vibration to sustain for a longer time, and there was no feedback." -Excerpted from Les Paul: In His Own Words

Description: Interactive music themed exhibit where guests can adjust the position and orientation of various blocks to modularly make a song.
Interactive experience that allows users to play different frequency sound through a tube and observe as the contents of the tube shaped to the sound wave being played.
Copy:
Seeing Sound
How would you measure the speed of sound?
In 1886, August Kundt generated a single frequency of sound - a pure tone inside a tube. Dust inside the tube began to vibrate and dance, forming the outline of the soundwave. Kundt then figured out that the distance between the dancing piles of dust is the wavelength of the sound wave. Since he knew the frequency of the sound wave, he could multiply that number by the wavelength and find the speed of sound in air.

Description: Exhibit that highlights Les Paul's The Octopus, the first ever multi-track recording system.
Copy:
The Octopus
Les got the idea for this monster back in 1953. He wanted true multi-track recording, a device that would allow him to record multiple, independent tracks that were synced together. His friends at Ampex had helped him in the past, and they jumped at the chance to build something so revolutionary. It took them about a year to build it, and it cost Les $14,000. Les wasn't happy. "The speeds were off, the EQ was unacceptable, and there was a million other bugs that had not been worked out", said Les. So he shipped it back. Ampex worked on it some more. They shipped it back. This went on for a while. Les still wasn't happy. Four years later, in 1957, Les and his design guy, Rein Narma, finally got it right, and Les was able to record. You're looking at the first true 8-track recorder, the machine that changed music forever.

Description: Experience that allows guests to play the Theremin, an electronic instrument that doesn't require physical contact from the user.
Copy:
Theremin
This instrument is "hands-off"! The Theremin makes sound without being touched. It works by detecting how close you are to its two antennas. The tube antenna controls pitch (how high or low the sound is), and the flat antenna controls volume (how loud or soft the sound is). Moving your hands closer or farther away from the antennas changes the electric charge, which the theremin translates into sound.

Description: Early-learning experience where guests can view Bernoulli's principle in action with plastic balls.
Copy:
Bernoulli's Principle & Flight
Slower moving fluids (liquid or gas) exert more pressure than faster moving fluids. An aircraft's wing is curved on top and flat on the bottom. Air traveling over the top of the wing moves faster than under the wing. This generates higher pressure on the bottom of the wing, causing lift.

Description: A four-stroke piston engine which guests can hand crank and ignite to operate.
Topics: engines, pistons, simple machines, physical activity
Copy:
Energy Into Motion
The force of the explosion drives a piston downward. The piston drives a connector rod. The connector rod drives the crankshaft. The crankshaft turns the up and down motion of the engine into a circular motion that drives the wheels.

Description: Life-sized excavator which guests can control to scoop wood chips.
Topics: construction, engines, simple machines, fluid dynamics
Copy:
Multiplying the Multiplier
A lever can help you lift a boulder. A lever and a hydraulic cylinder can help you move a mountain. On this excavator, each hydraulic cylinder is attached to a moving part of the excavator. The pressure from the hydraulic pump is multiplied by the cylinder and again by the boom, arm, and bucket, which act like levers.
The Hydraulic Circuit
A hydraulic circuit is kind of like an electrical circuit.
There are hoses instead of wires and fluid instead of electricity. Instead of the electromotive force (Volts) pushing electrons along, a pump pushes fluid through the circuit. In a hydraulic circuit, the engine turns the hydraulic pump. The pump pushes fluid through a hose to the control valve. Valves choose the route the fluid takes. For instance, the valve can route the fluid to extend or retract the cylinder's piston. The pistons inside the cylinders extend and contract the arm, and the bucket.
Why Hydraulic Power?
• Simplicity! Eliminate the gears, cams, chain drives, and pulleys.
• Efficiency! Fewer moving parts means a more efficient machine!
• Power! Transform small forces into incredibly large forces!
• Control! Manage large forces with small forces!
• Flexibility! Transmit force into difficult spaces!
FORCE
/FÖRS/
A push. A pull. A force is an interaction that changes the motion of an object.
PRESSURE 
/PRESHER/
Force exerted over a given area.

Description: Simulation experience where guests can digitally take control of an airplane using realistic controls.
Copy: *No central copy

Description: Using fluid dynamics, the user is able to spin a series of fans elsewhere in the exhibit.
Copy:
Fluid Power, Fluid Freedom.
Hydraulic power frees you from gears, cams, chain drives, and incredibly heavy motors. It allows you to design all kinds of wild and wonderful machines capable of doing incredible things.
Fluid Power is Flexible
Hydraulic Fluid transmits pressure in every direction, but fluid pressure can be guided easily through hoses. Hoses are small and bendable. You can route them wherever you need them to go. Hydraulic pumps are small and light. You can place them almost anywhere on your machine.

Description: Basic piston engine that highlights the four main steps in a piston engine's process.
Copy:
I: INTAKE
The piston moves downward and pulls a mixture of fuel and air into the cylinder. The intake valve is open.
2: COMPRESSION
The piston moves upward compressing the mixture of fuel and air. Both the intake valve and the exhaust valves are closed.
3: COMBUSTION
The mixture of compressed fuel and air is ignited by a spark from a spark plug. The force of the explosion drives the piston downward and provides the power to turn the crankshaft.
4: EXHAUST
The exhaust valve opens. The piston moves upward pushing the exhaust out of the engine. Ideally, at 800 revolutions per minute (rpm) a spark plug fires 400 times.

Description: Simulated helicopter controls that allows guests to manipulate basic controls while learning what they do.
Copy:
Collective Pitch Control
The Collective Control is the up and down control. If the helicopter is level, this will make it to go up or down, but if the helicopter is tilted forward, it will increase the speed.
Tail Rotor Pedals
The Tail Rotor Pedals, or Anti-Torque Pedals, are used to turn the helicopter to the left or to the right. The pilot pushes the left pedal to increase the pitch of the tail rotor and turn to the left. Pushing the right pedal decreases the pitch of the tail rotor and turns the helicopter to the right.
Cyclic Control Stick
The Cyclic Control Stick (Joystick) moves the helicopter forward and backward. Moving the stick forward and back will point the nose of the helicopter up or down. This is accomplished by changing the angle of the rotor blades.

Description: In this exhibit, visitors can directly compare different power outputs. Using hydraulics, they can lift themselves off the ground, showcasing its high power density. This experience is contrasted with an electric engine, which, due to its lower power density, cannot lift the user.
Copy:
Power Density
This small hydraulic pump is all you need to lift a bunch of your friends. It would take an electric motor about 10x larger and heavier to lift the same bunch of friends. Hydraulic pumps have a very high power density. There's a whole lot of power in a small package.
156LBS
A 40 hp A40-5 airplane engine weighs about 156 lbs.
520LBS
A 40 hp electric motor weighs about 520 lbs.
40LBS
A 40 hp hydraulic pump weighs about 40 lbs.

Description: Users assemble cars and test them to see how far they can travel. Once ready, they can set the pressure of a launcher and watch the affects it has on their creation.
Copy:
Where Does Energy Come From?
Your little race car runs on the energy stored in compressed air. You pumped the air into the car using the compressor. The energy you used to pump air into your car comes from the food you eat. The energy stored in the food you eat comes, directly or indirectly, from the sun.
Did You Know?
For every action there is an equal (in size) and opposite (in direction) reaction. Air rushes out of the car in one direction pushing the car in the other direction.
TRY OUT DIFFERENT CARS TO SEE HOW THEY COMPARE

Description: Guests use bottles and pressurized air to build their own rockets that can be launched up into the air.
Topics: aerodynamics, rockets, Isaac Newton, gravity, motion, physics
Copy:
Blast Off
A rocket's engine is also called a reaction engine after Newton's Third Law. Incredibly hot exhaust gas rushes downward pushing the rocket upward into space.
Did You Know?
It took nearly 300 years from the time Sir Isaac Newton mathematically described Gravity and Motion to the time Neil Armstrong took his historic first step on the moon.

Description: Informational panels located around the perimeter of the space that explains common physics concepts in accessible language.
Topics: physics, force, gravity, acceleration, friction, energy, time, reading-heavy
Copy:
What Is ENERGY?
That's a big question. Energy is... a thing. A property of matter. It can be turned into work, though not always. It can be stored, sometimes for millions or billions of years. It can be transferred from one form to another. Energy, to put it simply, "makes everything go". Energy makes humans go. We run on the chemical energy stored in food. This energy comes, indirectly, from the sun. We transform this energy into work and play and laughter and everything else. Energy makes our world go. Civilization runs on the chemical energy stored in stuff we set on fire - oil, natural gas, coal, garbage, wood, etc.* This energy comes, indirectly, from the sun. We transform this stored energy into heat and electricity, which we turn into work.
Energy cannot be created. It cannot be destroyed. It can only be transferred. But what is energy? That's a big question.
*Increasingly, we also transform the energy of wind, falling water, and the sun into heat and electricity and work.
What Is GRAVITY?
That depends on who you ask. Sir Isaac Newton described Gravity mathematically, but he had no idea what it was. He decided it was a Force. Other than that, he wouldn't even make a guess. Albert Einstein figured out that Gravity is really the warping of spacetime caused by matter. The Earth orbits the sun because the Sun's enormous mass warps the fabric of spacetime, creating a "dent" in the Universe that the Earth and the other planets follow. The Earth creates its own "dent" in the fabric of spacetime that the moon follows. You also make a
"dent" in the fabric of spacetime. Not a very big one, though.
What is ACCELERATION?
A skydiver leaps out of an airplane and plummets towards Earth. She accelerates in a downward direction at roughly 10 meters per second per second. Soon there is a balance between air resistance and gravity, as our skydiver reaches a constant speed of 54 meters per second or 122 miles per hour. 122 miles per hour is not an optimal landing speed, so our skydiver (as intelligent as she is intrepid), opens her parachute. The parachute increases the amount of air resistance, slowing her descent. She accelerates again, this time in the opposite direction. Acceleration is a change in speed and direction in a given amount of time. So it can mean both "speeding up" and "slowing down". What we call "deceleration" is simply acceleration in the opposite direction.
What Is FRICTION?
Why do your hands get warm when you rub them together rapidly for a few seconds? Why do car engines need oil? Friction. Slide two surfaces against each other and the result is friction. Friction is a resistive force that slows things down as it transforms motion into heat. Friction also happens within fluids and inside materials as they bend. Your hands get warm because friction transforms the motion of your hands into heat. Your car needs oil because without it, all those moving parts in the engine would grind together creating an incredible amount of wear and an incredible amount of heat in a very short amount of time. Friction isn't all bad. There's plenty of friction between the road and the tires on your car, which allows you to do neat things like steer and turn.
What Is TIME?
We understand time on a human scale - moments, days, seasons, and years. We measure Time by the periodic motion of pendulums or the periodic vibrations of quartz crystals and cesium atoms. We use Time to coordinate our lives. But what is Time? What is it made of? We know that it is part of the fabric of the universe, that it is bound up with entropy, that events are irreversible, that we remember the past but not the future. We know that in the far distant future, when the universe reaches a fully disordered state, time will cease to be. Of course, the most important question is... can we build a time machine and go see it?
What Is FORCE?
A force is a push or pull in a given direction. The Force is an energy field created by all living things that surrounds us and penetrates us and binds the galaxy together.

Description: Informational panels located around the perimeter of the space that explains Newton's Laws in accessible language.
Copy:
Meet ISAAC NEWTON
Isaac Newton was an English physicist, mathematician, astronomer, and chemist. Building on the work of Galileo and Johannes Kepler, Newton mathematically described the Laws of Motion and Gravity way back in 1687. He also invented Calculus. Newton didn't get everything right (honestly, who does?), but he got a lot right. He helped build the foundations of modern science.
"I do not know what I may appear to the world, but to myself I seem to have been only like a boy playing on the sea-shore... whilst the great ocean of truth lay all undiscovered before me." - Isaac Newton
Newton's First Law of Motion INERTIA
Place a soccer ball on a field, and it just sits there. The forces acting on the soccer ball - gravity and the upward force of the ground holding up the ball - are balanced. The ball is at rest. Unless something happens to it, the soccer ball will stay at rest until the end of time. That's inertia, a property of matter. Now take that soccer ball, get in a rocket, and soar into interstellar space. Put on your spacesuit, grab the soccer ball, and exit the rocket. Give the soccer ball a good kick. At first the soccer ball will accelerate until it reaches a constant speed. If no other forces act on the soccer ball, it will travel at a constant speed in a constant direction until the end of time. This, too, is inertia. Newton's First Law states that objects tend to remain at rest or in motion at a constant speed unless acted upon by an outside, unbalanced force.
Newton's Second Law of Motion FORCE = MASS x ACCELERATION
You're on a soccer field. In front of you is a soccer ball at rest. The forces acting on the soccer ball are balanced.
You are about to change that. You give the soccer ball a big kick. You have provided an outside, unbalanced force. And the soccer ball is no longer at rest. It has accelerated and is sailing through the air down the field. How much force did you give the soccer ball? What was its rate of acceleration? What is the mass of the soccer ball? Newton's Second Law allows you to figure all of this out. The Second Law also states that the rate of acceleration depends on the mass of the object and the size of the force. With a good kick, you can send a soccer ball down the field. The same kick will not send a car down the field. A car, as you already know, has more mass than a soccer ball. Don't kick cars.
Newton's Third Law of Motion ACTION & REACTION
Go ahead and jump straight up into the air. Well done. You used your legs and feet to push yourself upward against the Earth. You also pushed the entire Earth downward with exactly the same amount of force. Newton's Third Law of Motion states that for every action there is an equal (in size) and opposite (in direction) reaction. You jumped up. The entire Earth moved downward. Just a very little bit. The Earth is much more massive than you are.

Description: Users crank a generator to build power within capacitors. Using electromagnetism, the ring is launched upward.
Topics: aerodynamics, physics, rockets, electromagnet, gravity, motors
Copy:
Crank the generator to charge the capacitors. Flip the switch, and launch the aluminum ring into the air.
How It Works
Current flows to the electromagnet. The electromagnet generates a magnetic field and induces magnetic field in the aluminum ring. The magnetic fields repel each other, forcing the ring upward.
Did You Know?
A generator and a motor are essentially the same thing. A generator turns motion into electricity. A motor turns electricity into work. A generator can be a motor, and a motor can be a generator.
Something Curious
Which ring sails higher? The smaller, lighter ring? Or the larger, heavier ring? Do you know why?

Description: Using aerodynamics, guests can attach a sail to a car and watch as the wind propels it forwards.
Topics: aerodynamics, sailing, friction, cars, sailboats, physics
Copy:
How Can a Sailboat Sail Into the Wind?
How Can it Sail Faster than the Wind?
A sail doesn't just catch the air and pull the boat along like a reverse parachute. A sail is really a wing turned on its side. Air flows faster over the curved side of the sail, creating high pressure on the other side. This lifting force pushes the boat both sideways and forward. The strength and directions of the lifting force depend on the angle of the sail. How does a sailboat go forward if the lifting force is also pushing it sideways? The sailboat has another wing in the water, sometimes more than one. The rudder and centerboard cancel out most of the sideways force. The sailboat moves mostly forward.

Description: Users can make custom propellors with paper cones and scissors. Once complete, they can test their creations to see how aerodynamic they are.
Copy:
Balanced Forces
An upward force from the column of air meets the downward force of gravity. Can you make the two forces balance each other out?
Customize a Flyer!
Experiment with different cuts on a paper cone to see how it flies.

Description: Guests use workout machines (rowing machine and workout bike) where their energy is converted to power. There are payoffs on the back wall that require certain energy thresholds; if a user reaches the threshold the payoffs are activated.
Copy:
The Power of You
Students from the Stockholm Academy of Dramatic Arts asked Robert Förstemann to make them some toast. They weren't hungry - they wanted to demonstrate how much power we use compared to how much we could possibly generate ourselves. Robert Förstemann is not a chef - he is a former world champion track cyclist and Olympic medalist from Germany. And the toaster wasn't plugged into the wall. It was plugged into a stationary bike with a generator. Förstemann hopped on the bike and began to pedal. He fought and strained and gave it everything he had. It wasn't easy. Using only muscle power, he generated around 700 watts for about two minutes - a massive effort for a human. Förstemann was completely exhausted, but he managed to make toast. Your toaster is not exhausted after it makes toast. Electricity does a tremendous amount of work for us. How much power can you generate on these bikes?
Cycling to Power
What's Going On? You pedal for 30 seconds. Your effort is measured in kilowatt hours. We multiply your effort by minutes. That's how long you'd have to pedal to make one of the gadgets run for X amount of time. A gadget runs for X amount of time as the kilowatt hours count down.

Description: Guests can compete in a Jeopardy style game show with questions regarding energy.
Copy:
Your Electric Brain
Your brain is astonishingly efficient considering it's the most complex thing in the universe. It runs on roughly 20 watts, enough to power two LED bulbs. A computer with the same abilities would probably need around a billion watts of power. The billions of neurons in your brain form trillions of connections. Electrical impulses zip along, hopping from neuron to neuron, carrying all kinds of information. Your senses, thoughts, and emotions are electric.

Description: Guests can activate a solar panel and watch as the energy they capture with it is converted to electrolysis to produce an explosion.
Topics: energy, sustainability, hydrogen, solar energy, animation, explosion, batteries
Copy:
Electrolysis
Using solar power to produce hydrogen might be part of our sustainable energy future. The sun’s radiant energy is converted to electrical energy by photovoltaic panels. This energy is stored in batteries that can be used to power electrolyzers, devices that split water into hydrogen and oxygen gases. Hydrogen and oxygen can be ignited for energy, the energy is sent off to be used, and water is all that’s left. Energy from sunlight and water = nearly zero greenhouse gas emissions!
Solar Powered
Feel the power of the sun! You might have seen the Solar Tree on the Front Lawn at Discovery World, but you probably didn’t notice the extensive PV array on our roof, spanning over 20,000 square feet (about the size of four basketball courts).
Photovoltaic (PV) Panel
A device that captures radiant energy and converts it into electricity. Not to be confused with solar panels; both convert the sun’s energy, but solar panels produce heat rather than electricity.
Hydrogen Electrolysis
The process of splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen using an electric current. The electric current is provided by a device called an electrolyzer.
Radiant Energy
Solar radiation is absorbed by PV panels for renewable energy production.
Electrical Energy
Radiant energy is converted to electrical energy by the PV panel. It is then sent to a battery to be stored.
Explosive Energy
Igniting the hydrogen with some oxygen creates a powerful (and clean) explosion.
Thermal Energy
The heat from the reaction can be released or used for another purpose.

Description: Guests can manipulate different tubs and pathways to watch gravity take a ball down to the end.
Copy:
Water Power in Wisconsin
We Energies operates 13 hydroelectric power plants, two of which are in Wisconsin. The first is on the Brule River near Florence. It was constructed in 1919 and can generate up to 5,300 kilowatts. That's enough to power 4,416 toasters. The other is on the Pine River, also near Florence. It was constructed in 1922 and can generate up to 3,600 kilowatts, which is enough to power 3,000 toasters.
Solar Energy
Each day, the Sun does a tremendous amount of work lifting billions of tons of water into the atmosphere. The Sun's energy is stored in this water vapor as gravitational potential energy.
Kinetic Energy
Eventually, the water vapor condenses. Clouds form. The water falls as rain or snow then flows downhill into rivers and eventually back to the ocean.
Electrical Energy
Flowing water can be used to make turbines spin, which causes generators to spin. Generators transform this kinetic energy into electrical energy.

Description: Physical interactive where guests can run in place to generate power for their fictional cities.
Copy:
A Balance of Power
How does We Energies generate and send electricity to Milwaukee right when it's needed? By using multiple types of power plants, each with different strengths. To determine which plants to operate when, We Energies considers the amount of electricity the city needs at various times alongside conditions (like weather) that impact the availability of different power sources. Work together to make all the buildings light up.
Build power plants fast & early.
Some plants require more work to build than others.
Watch the weather.
Storms, wind, the temperature, and the sun can affect how much power is needed and how much you can generate.
Choose the most efficient plant.
Some plants require less work to generate the same amount of energy.
Meet high demand.
Run fastest at dawn and dusk when most people are at home using power.

Description: Experience that shows a user their own reflection through an infrared camera.
Copy:
Invisible Light
All objects emit infrared light. Some more than others.
You emit more infrared light than an ice cube. Some animals like pit vipers and mosquitos can see infrared light. We feel it as heat.
Visible Light
Most light energy is invisible to us. The energy that our eyes can detect is a mere sliver of the electromagnetic spectrum, Infrared cameras translate invisible energy into images we can see.
Invisible Light Into Information
Infrared cameras are used by firefighters to find people trapped in burning buildings. They are used by electrical workers to find failing equipment. Some astronomers use infrared telescopes. Some cars have infrared cameras that help drivers see at night. Humans use the entire electromagnetic spectrum to explore, discover, and communicate.

Description: Rotating, circular bench that shows an abstract representation of the energy produced by the sun.
Copy:
The Sun, The Source
A seething, roiling sphere of incandescent plasma. A massive fusion reactor sustained by its own gravitational collapse. It is mind-bogglingly huge and ridiculously hot. Please don't stare at it. Each year, the Earth receives around 3,800,000 exajoules of energy from the Sun - the ultimate source of energy. It's a staggering amount of energy yet only a tiny fraction of the Sun's total output. This energy drives weather and life. Energy cannot be created on earth - it can only be transformed from solar energy into different types of energy. Plants transform about 3,000 exajoules of this solar energy through photosynthesis. Humans transform and use around 500 exajoules of energy each year. Our energy comes from different sources, including coal, oil, natural gas, water and wind, and directly from the Sun itself. Our planet receives more energy from the Sun in 90 minutes than people use in a year. If we are clever enough, we will never run out of energy. If we are incredibly clever, we might build an entirely new energy future.
The Fusion Engine
The Sun produces energy through the process of thermonuclear fusion. In the Sun's core, the extreme pressure fuses hydrogen atoms together, producing helium atoms. This fusion releases a monstrous amount of energy in the form of high-energy gamma rays. As these gamma rays bounce their way from the center of the Sun to its surface, they lose some energy and become mostly ultraviolet, visible, and infrared light. Energy from the Sun's core can take anywhere from 10,000 to 170,000 years to reach its surface. From there, it takes about eight minutes to reach the Earth. It takes 5,5 hours for light from the Sun to reach Pluto.
Transforming the Sun
The energy stored in oil, coal, and natural gas comes from the Sun. The energy stored in the wind and flowing water comes from the Sun. Even the energy stored in the food you eat comes from the Sun. We transform this stored energy. Wood into heat. Wind into the movement of ships. Water into the motion of millstones. Food into muscle, work, ideas, and technology. Coal into heat into steam into spinning turbines and generators into electricity. Electricity into light, heat, work, information, computation, and machine intelligence. The Sun Powers Life. The Sun Powers Civilization. The Sun Powers You.

Description: Large model that creates a mini-tornado using water vapor
Copy:
Destruction
Tornadoes can toss cars and trucks around like toys, rip trees out of the ground, and tear buildings apart. Pound for pound, tornadoes are the most energetic and destructive storms on the planet.
Wisconsin Tornadoes
Wisconsin averages 23 tornadoes each year. We had 62 back in 2005. We only had four in 2012. Wisconsin tornadoes, on average, last for under 10 minutes and touch ground for three to five miles. The Chetek tornado in May 2017 was on the ground for about two hours and cut an 83-mile path through Wisconsin. Chetek is 40 miles north of Eau Claire.
Heat Energy
Warm, moist air lifts upward as cooler air sinks downward causing rotation within a thunderstorm.
Kinetic Energy
A funnel of swirling air snakes downward from the storm to the ground with winds that can reach speeds of over 300 miles per hour.

Description: Guests put their hand into a chainmail glove and watch as electricity arcs and touches their fingertips.
Copy:
Could we Harness Lightning Energy?
We could, but it probably wouldn't be worth it. Lightning produces a huge amount of energy within a short amount of time. Capturing it is possible, but storing that energy would be difficult and expensive. Lightning is also wildly unpredictable and thunderstorms are somewhat rare, so it would be an unreliable source of power. And even if we could capture and store a significant percentage of lightning energy, it would amount to an insignificant fraction of the world's energy needs.
Kinetic Energy
Rain, hail, and frozen water collide inside a storm cloud.
The kinetic energy of these collisions is transformed.
Electrical Energy
The top of the cloud becomes positively charged and the base of the cloud becomes negatively charged. Because like charges repel, everything on the ground underneath the cloud becomes positively charged as electrons scramble to get out of the way.
Fingers of electrical energy called "stepped leaders" reach down from the cloud to the ground, searching for the path of least resistance. The ground sends up a bolt of energy called a "streamer" to meet them. The leader and streamer connect, creating a conductive pathway.
Heat, Light, Electrical, and Sound Energy
That connection creates a ferocious blast of light, heat, sound, and electrical energy - lightning and thunder!

Description: Guests are able to touch a Van de Graaff generator and experience static electricity.
Copy:
Kinetic Energy Into Electric Potential
Inside the Van de Graaff generator, a drive belt spins over rollers made of different materials, which separates positive and negative charges. A metal brush at the base of the generator conducts negative charge to the ground. Another metal brush at the top of the generator conducts excess positive charge to the metal collector dome. The dome becomes positively charged.
Why do you get Shocked?
There's a big difference in electrical charge between you and the Van de Graaff generator. That electrical charge is looking for the path of least resistance. When you reach out to touch the metal dome, you become the path of least resistance. The charge jumps from the dome to you.
When you hold your hand on the dome, you become positively charged.
Share this Excess Positive Charge with your Friends!
This shock is harmless. An electrical outlet or a power line charge is much more powerful and can be deadly. Do not play with electrical outlets or power lines.

Description: Interactive experience where guests scan RFID pucks and can see information about an artifact that the puck represents.
Copy:
A Story in Pieces
What do you look for when you analyze and remake an artifact?
MATERIALS: What is the artifact made of? Where did the materials come from?
METHODS: How was the artifact made? Which tools and techniques were used?
USE: Was the artifact valuable, ceremonial, or a common, everyday item?
To piece together the story of a people, you must first reconstruct the fragments of the things they left behind. Place the icon on the lighted circle. Rotate the icon to reconstruct the artifact.

Description: Experience that explains dendrochronology, the study of dating trees based off of their rings. Users are able to touch a tree that has been growing since the 18th century.
Copy:
Dendrochronology
The Study of Tree Rings Through Time
Developed in the early 1900s by the astronomer A. E. Douglass, who when he discovered that tree rings record sunspot activity. Each tree ring is a measure of time, and trees from the same area have very similar patterns of ring growth. Wooden beams and timber from a site can be accurately dated by matching the rings to a regions timeline. The first archaeological application occured in 1919, when Douglass used tree-ring analysis to measure the construction dates of two sites in the U.S. southwest.

Description: Interactive exhibit that allows users to scroll a small wheel and view different layers of a CT scan taken of the Meresamun Mummy.
Copy:
Meresamun Mummy
Computerized Tomography (CT) scanning is a technology used by archaeologists to digitally excavate mummies without damaging their delicate interiors. This is a CT scan of a circa 3000-year-old Egyptian mummy, now housed at the Oriental Museum of Chicago. According to the hieroglyphs on the sarcophagus, the mummy's name was Meresamun, which means "She Lives for the Amun”. Meresamun was a musician who held the title "Singer in the Interior Temple of Amun". The CT scan reveals that Meresamun was a woman with strong cheekbones and wide-set eyes. She had a slight overbite and retained all of her teeth, which were worn down by years of eating coarse, stone ground flour. The scan also reveals a large amount of linen used by her embalmers to wrap the body and fill empty organ cavities. Can you find other physical evidence about how Meresamun might have lived? Used with permission by the Oriental Institute of Chicago.

Description: Various informational panels detailing important locations in Milwaukee's history.
Copy:
Prehistoric Burial Mound
The last of a group of Native American Mounds formerly located on a Stone Age village site near this spot and destroyed in recent years. Several were of larger size. Also the last of many fine groups of burial, linear, and animal shaped mounds formerly located within the present limits of the City of Milwaukee. Effigy mounds are burial sites made of earth and are common in Wisconsin's landscape. Many were constructed in the shapes of like animals and spirits. Other mounds are conical or linear shapes. Another variation in the style of mounds is the Panther Intaglio in Fort Atkinson, which is an indentation in the ground that fills up with water when it rains. Most mounds were built by Late Woodland Period people, between A.D. 750 and 1200. More often than not, effigy mounds occur in groups along with other kinds of mounds. During the 1800s, European-American archaeologists assumed indigenous people did not build the mounds and attributed them to a nebulous race of "mound-builders." Excavations of these mounds in the late 1800s revealed native artifacts and skeletal remains, settling the debate.
More than 3,000 effigy sites, that are known of, once existed in Wisconsin, but fewer than 10 percent of those remain.
First African American Church Built in Wisconsin
St. Mark African Methodist Episcopal Church, the first African American church built in Wisconsin, once stood on this site. The property was purchased in 1869, the year the congregation was organized. Construction on the St. Mark A.M.E. church began in November 1886, under the direction of Rev. William R. Alexander, pastor. Dedicatory services were held on April 3, 1887. The St. Mark congregation spent 43 years at this site, during which time the membership grew and the church, known as the Friendly Church, became the center of religious, civic, and cultural affairs for the African American community.
Bayview Rolling Mill
Near this site in Bay View stood the Milwaukee Iron Company rolling mill, the first major heavy industry in the region and an important producer of iron and steel for the Midwest. The mill, which opened in 1868, transformed ore from Dodge County and Lake Superior area mines into iron products, including thousands of tons of rail for the region's growing railroads. By 1885, more than 1,500 people were employed at the plant, some recruited from the iron-producing districts of the British Isles, and the village of Bay View grew from a rural crossroads into an industrial community surrounding the rolling mill. On May 5, 1886, the mill was the scene of a major labor disturbance. Nearly 1500 strikers from around Milwaukee marched on the Bay View mill to dramatize their demand for an eight-hour work day. The local militia, called to the scene by Governor Jeremiah Rusk, fired on the crowd, killing seven people. The mill closed in 1929, and the buildings were demolished a decade later. But the community of Bay View remains, a neighborhood of mill workers' houses, shops, and churches.
More Copy:
Lueddemann's-On-The River
This park played a key role in Shorewood's development. In 1872, Frederick A. Lueddemann opened Lueddemann's-On-The-River on this site in the Town of Milwaukee. Otto Zwietusch bought the resort in 1876 and renamed it Mineral Springs Park. Envisioning a landscaped urban retreat, he replaced the original building with a large building featuring apartments, a restaurant, and billiard rooms. The park was purchased in 1900 and renamed Coney Island. Its owners added a roller coaster, loud music and garish lights. These changes prompted growing dissatisfaction with the Town of Milwaukee which was collecting license fees. In 1900, the community incorporated as the Village of East Milwaukee, renamed Shorewood in 1917. Ravenna Park, the last in a succession of parks, closed in 1916. The grounds were subdivided and the structures removed. Only Hubbard Park remains from the original Lueddemann's-On-The-River.
National Soldiers' Home
The Wisconsin Soldiers' Home Association was formed in 1864 by a coalition of women's charitable organizations led by Lydia Hewitt, Hannah Vedder, and Mrs. E. L. Buttrick of Milwaukee. The Association raised funds to endow a hospital where sick and wounded Civil War soldiers could receive medical treatment and long-term domiciliary care. After securing a state appropriation of $5000, the Association staged a spectacular public event known as the Soldiers' Home Fair, which opened in Milwaukee on June 29, 1865, and raised more than $110,000. The proceeds from the Soldiers' Home Fair enabled the Association to purchase land and establish a hospital. In 1867, the Association transferred its property and remaining funds to the federal government for the establishment of the National Asylum for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers, Northwestern Branch. Dr. Erastus B. Wolcott of Milwaukee, the state's surgeon general during the Civil War, was appointed by Congress to head the governing board of the Home. In 1869, the noted architect Edward Townsend Mix designed the High Victorian Gothic structure "Old Main," now known as Building No. 2. The hospital was renamed the Clement J. Zablocki Veterans Administration Medical Center in 1985.
Rescue of Joshua Glover
Joshua Glover was a runaway slave who sought freedom in Racine in 1852. In 1854, his Missouri owner used the Fugitive Slave Act to apprehend him. This 1850 law permitted slave catchers to cross state lines to capture escaped slaves. Glover was taken to Milwaukee and imprisoned. Word spread about Glover's incarceration and a great crowd gathered around the jail demanding his release. They beat down the jail door and released Joshua Glover. He was eventually escorted to Canada and safety. The Glover incident helped galvanize abolitionist sentiment in Wisconsin. This case eventually led the state supreme court to defy the federal government by declaring the Fugitive Slave Act unconstitutional.

Description: Informational exhibit that highlights historical examples of real mummies and fake ones found throughout history.
Copy:
How do I tell what it is?
Objects may not always be what they seem. Knowing where you are in its timeline is as important as when and where the object comes from.
Sherit, the mummy, was actually a child.
Advanced technology has allowed reserchers to look inside the sarcophogus of this 2000-year-old mummy from Eygpt. So much information was gathered that scientists were able to reconstruct her face without ever opening her casket.
Petrified Man? The Cardiff Giant.
This 10 foot-tall "petrified man" was found in 1869. George Hull had a carver work a piece of gypsum into the figure of a man, stain it with acids, and beat the figure with a board full of needles to "age" the stone. Although declared a fake by archaeologists and geologists, it didn't stop PT Barnum from forming a plaster replica of the Giant, then calling the original a fake.

Description: Five virtual reality spaces where guests can choose from a small selection of games and play for up to five minutes.
Copy:
How Does the VR System Know Where I Am?
Lighthouse Sensors are active, infrared sensors that emit a burst of invisible light 60 times per second. They also send a beam of invisible laser light sweeping across the room. The Vive headset is covered in photosensors that start counting the millisecond they detect these bursts of infrared light. They stop counting when they're hit by the laser. The Lighthouses use this information to determine the position of the headset. Since you are wearing the headset, the Lighthouse Sensors know exactly where you are. The Vive controllers also 'talk' to the Lighthouse Sensors, helping track your actions.

Welcome to the Aphotic Zone 
Our final stop is the aphotic zone! The only light you’ll find here comes from the animals themselves. Many deep sea creatures have a special ability called bioluminescence, or “living light”. Chemicals in the animal mix to give o light that can be blue, violet, green-yellow, and sometimes red. Bioluminescence is useful for lots of reasons, like communication, camouflage, and luring prey!

Copy:
Welcome to the Disphotic Zone 
Dive deeper into the disphotic zone! It’s pretty dark here, since almost all light has been absorbed. A small amount of blue light still made it because of its higher energy. That means that down here a red fish will appear gray or black. Does anyone have a flashlight?

Description: At the most easternly section of the experience, the Euphotic Zone highlights plant and animal life that is able to live here due to the high amount of light that gets through.
Topics: water, diving, ocean, fish, Great Lakes
Copy:
Welcome to the Euphotic Zone 
Let’s go for a swim through the euphotic zone! This zone is the only place where there’s enough sunlight for photosynthesis to occur – meaning you’ll find lots of plants here! Since sunlight can travel through the water up to a point, divers can enjoy seeing red, yellow, green, and purple organisms, whose colors are not visible at deeper levels.

Description: Mechanical lungs that demonstrate how breathing works at different elevations.
Copy:
Could I Breathe Underwater? 
Our chests need the pressure on the outside to equal what it is inside our lungs in order to work. Scuba tanks and regulators keep the pressure where it should be to make sure our lungs don’t SQUISH or POP! Fun Fact: Dolphins have collapsible lungs and really strong muscles that let them dive deep underwater.

Copy:
Microscope 
Plankton are teeny (some are smaller than a red blood cell) and go wherever the water pushes them. As the base of the food chain, which plankton are here and which are missing is important – every water animal depends on these tiny plankton somehow. Use the microscope to see them up close! Fun Fact: A baleen whale eats thousands of pounds of plankton every day!

Description: Model representation of the locks found throughout the Great Lakes. Guests can adjust the water level to see a model boat rise and lower.
Topics: shipping, Great Lakes, boats, transportation, engineering
Copy:
Water Locks
Water Locks... invented by the Chinese a thousand years ago... allow ships to pass back and forth from lakes of different heights, by a simple set of valves. Water will always seek its own level, so gravity does all the work... no pumps... no power required! Gates (yellow) - only open when water level is equal on one side or the other - allowing a ship to go into the lock. Then the gate is closed and a valve is opened to raise or lower the water - taking the ship with it. Then the opposite gate is opened to let the ship pass through. Try operating the locks below!
Lake Huron 557 ft.
Open this valve and the water in the lock will seek Lake Huron level and a ship in the lock will be lowered to Huron.
Lake Superior 601 ft.
Open this valve and the water in the lock will seek Lake Superior level.

Description: Overlook of Great Lakes Future that contains weather controls for GLF and information on Great Lakes weather phenomenon.
Topics: weather, national parks, Great Lakes, scenic view, reading-heavy
Copy:
Apostle Islands
Look below at Great Lakes Future… we are roughly located just over one of Wisconsin’s most unique geographical regions - the Apostle Islands! These 22 islands and their natural marvels have been closely studied by scientists for decades to learn more about how weather continuously shapes the land.
Weathered Wonderland (Sea Caves)
The Apostle Islands’ sea caves have formed over centuries through wave erosion, water freezing and thawing, and the slow crumble of the sandstone rock along the shoreline. In the winter, the caves transform into a sparkling, icy wonderland, filled with hanging icicles and beautiful frost patterns.
Water, Wind, & Weather (Lake Effect Snow)
One of the most unique weather patterns in the Great Lakes region is lake effect snow. Lake effect snow occurs when cold air from the north blows over the warmer lake water, cooling down quickly and picking up extra moisture. That moisture turns into snow and can bring massive amounts of snowfall to nearby land. 
It’s Cooler By The Lake (Microclimates)
Have you noticed that Milwaukee seems like it is “shielded” from certain weather? Water changes temperature more slowly than air. Due to the size of Lake Michigan, the lakefront of Milwaukee can be warmer in the winter, cooler in the summer, or even have entirely different weather, altogether.
Bats of the Apostles
The Apostle Islands host up to seven bat species. The only true-flying mammals, bats accomplish flight through elongated hands and patagia (bat wings). Bats benefit their ecosystems as well as the agricultural industry via pest management. All bats found in the islands are insect-eaters. Little brown bats eat up to 1,000 mosquitoes per night!
Great Lakes Facts
Tornadoes can form over the waters of the Great Lakes. These “waterspouts” are most common in the autumn months.
During winter, “ice volcanoes” can occur in the Great Lakes when water is forced up through openings in the ice, resembling volcanic eruptions.
The Great Lakes region experiences a unique weather phenomenon called "seiche" - a sudden change in water level caused by atmospheric pressure changes or wind.
Lake Superior's "Three Sisters" phenomenon, three large and closely spaced unpredictable waves, is thought to have contributed to the sinking of the Edmund Fitzgerald in 1975.

Description: Archimedes screw that users can twist and observe a series of plastic balls move upward. Plastic balls are meant to represent water.
Copy:
There’s Something Screwy About this Wedge
This simple machine has been around for over 2000 years. It's called the Archimedes Screw, though Archimedes did not invent it. The Ancient Egyptians may have invented it, though it's possible that this simple machine is even older. There's still some debate among people who debate these sorts of things. The Archimedes Screw is a long wedge spiraled around a core inside a tube. As you turn the machine, the screw draws whatever it is you're lifting upward. Versions of the Archimedes Screw-the screw conveyor and the screw pump-are used to harvest grain, move rock, propel boats, and pump water.

Description: Activity that shows the power of levers by allowing users to lift a large rock using one. Users can adjust the length of the lever to have a better understanding of fulcrums.
Copy:
Being Stronger Can Make You Stronger
You have a rock to lift. It weighs 100 pounds. You could try to pick it up, but you're smarter than that. You're so smart that you've brought a lever. There are two parts to a lever: the beam and the fulcrum. The fulcrum is the pivot point, the part that the beam rotates on.
Use the lever to multiply force and lift that rock!

Description: Guests can spin a large horizontal screw that lifts a large and heavy section of a wooden beam found in a house.
Copy:
Lift a House with One Hand
This amazing screw gives you an incredible mechanical advantage. Turn the wheel and you can lift a car, a house, even a tall building. Of course, you're trading that mechanical advantage for distance. You have to turn the wheel a lot to lift the load a little.

Description: A chair connected to pulleys that allows users to sit in it and lift themselves up.
Copy:
Give Yourself a Lift
With the help of a chair, a few feet of rope, and two pulleys, you can lift yourself into the air. A pulley with one wheel changes the direction of a force. You pull down, but you go up. Pulleys with more than one wheel also change the magnitude of the force. There are two pulleys here, each with more than one wheel. They provide the mechanical advantage you need to give yourself a lift.

Description: A visual functioning display of how pistons in an engine work. Alternating pressure on three pistons kinetically powers and rotates the fan.
Copy:
This is a Pump Car. You are the Engine.
Push on a yellow piston with your feet. Turn the fan. Work together to generate a refreshing breeze.
The Crankshaft
Like a lever, a crankshaft changes the direction of a force. When you push on a piston, the crankshaft changes the downward direction of that push into spinning. Or, to make it more science-y, the crankshaft transforms reciprocating motion (up and down or back and forth) into rotational motion (spinning). The crankshaft is located underneath the front of the Pump Car. Take a look!

Description: A pre-cut log that is spring loaded back as one piece. Users can insert a wedge to observe it split back open.
Copy:
Split the Difference with a Wedge
The wedge is an incredibly versatile and useful simple machine. Use them to split, chop, saw, carve, and cut. A wedge can even hold open a door! Wedges translate force to right angles. When you push down on a wedge, it pushes outward. A skinnier or sharper wedge has a greater splitting force.

Description: Windlass structure that uses a set of pulleys and a wheel to allow users to lift a large ice block.
Topics: simple machines, lifting, pulley, history, engineering
Copy:
The Windlass
A windlass is a machine that combines a wheel and axle, a rope, and a pulley. The wheel and axle multiply force like a lever. The pulley changes the direction of the force.
Windlasses have been around since at least the Ancient Greeks.
Lift 300 Pounds All by Yourself
This block of pretend ice weighs 300 lbs. The smaller wheel has a diameter of 30 inches. The large wheel has a diameter of 60 inches. Which wheel is easier to turn? Why do you think that is?

Bulkhead
A substantial upright partition usually built athwart ship (across the ship's width) to add strength and separate the ship into compartments that prevent the spread of fire or water.
Forecastle

Copy:
What are "sea legs"?
Fluids in the inner ear detect the bobbing and rolling motions of the waves, but your eyes think the surroundings are stable because your body is moving with the ship. This conflict creates motion sickness. A sailor who can overcome it has "earned their sea legs!"
